newsitem.title: USA: Continental says met pilots' wage demands.
newsitem.headline: Continental says met pilots' wage demands.

text.p: A Continental Airlines Inc spokesman on Friday said the carrier has offered its pilots' union a 38 percent wage hike in a new labor contract.
"We offered a 38 percent increase over three years, which is exactly what they've asked for publicly," Continental spokesman Ned Walker said.
But Walker said the union in closed-door negotiations has taken a different position, seeking $1.4 billion in wage increases over the next three years or about double current salaries.
"What they've asked for publicly and what they've proposed to us are inconsistent," Walker said.
A union official earlier today said the carrier made a "low ball" offer that fell well short of the union's demand for a 38 percent wage increase.
The two sides are scheduled to begin meeting with a federal mediator on Wednesday in Washington, D.C. to resume talks aimed at reaching a new labor agreement by June 30.
"It is our strong preference that from here on, both parties limit their comments to the bargaining table," Walker said.
